title: Awareness and control of hypertension and hypercholesterolaemia in France and Northern Ireland

prompts.answer:
Keywords Receptor /C1Adrenergic /C1Alpha-1 /C1
Autoantibody /C1Hypertension /C1Vasoconstriction
Introduction
Deﬁned as a rise in blood pressure of unknown cause,
essential hypertension increases risk for cerebral, cardiac,
and renal events [ 15,16,23]. Essential hypertension plays
a major etiologic role in the development of major car-diovascular disease such as cerebrovascular disease,
ischemic heart disease, cardiac and renal failure, and is
becoming an increasingly common health problem world-wide [ 24,28]. In industrialized countries, the risk of
becoming hypertensive during a lifetime exceeds 90%.
Worldwide, hypertension is estimated to cause 7.1 milliondeaths and 4.5% of the disease burden annually [ 27].
Despite the availability of effective and safe antihyper-
tensive drugs, hypertension and its concomitant risk factorsremain uncontrolled in a great proportion of patients. The
mechanisms responsible for the development of essential
hypertension remain incompletely understood.
There exists evidence suggesting primary or secondary
alterations in the function of the immune system may play
a role in both the initiation and maintenance of thehypertensive state in both animal models and humans
[4,6]. Investigators have reported the immunogenic
importance of the second extracellular loop of the humana
1-adrenoceptors ( a1-AR) [ 7], and the high frequency of
patients with primary hypertension [ 9,19] and malignant
hypertension [ 17] harboring a1-AAB. a1-AAB has been
demonstrated to exert a positive chronotropic effect on
isolated neonatal rat cardiomyocytes [ 19], and stimulating
their activity via activation of L-type calcium channels in
